intro: Clitandra laurifolia, commonly known as the white-flowered tamarind, is a tropical tree native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its glossy, dark green leaves and fragrant, white flowers that bloom in clusters. The plant produces small, round fruits that contain a single seed surrounded by a hard, woody pulp. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has traditional uses in local medicine. Clitandra laurifolia thrives in humid, tropical climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth.
